channel.name: How are actions implemented under the hood?

messages.content:
Why can I only choose to reduce all of them at once?
How is this represented in the circuit?

Hello Las, thanks a lot for the question. First of all, you do not have to reduce all of them at once. You can put some state hash of the actions as an argument to the reducer, so that only the actions after that point are reduced during that method. Likewise, once the reducer reduces the state, it returns you the calculated state, and the new state hash. We usually save this in a seperate zkApp state so that you do not reduce the same actions over and over again. You can read more about it here: https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/o1js/actions-and-reducer. Moreover, you can see an example use case here in the voting example in o1js repo: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/main/src/examples/zkapps/voting/voting.ts. As you see, there are two states in the smart contract there: committed and accumulated votes. Accumulated votes represent the actions you have reduced before, so that you do not count all action again and again.
Yes but how is this represented in the circuit?
And you say "after" so it's LIFO?
About the implementation, I am not completely sure about the details. However, you can read more about the logic in here: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/265.

embeds.title: Issues · o1-labs/o1js
embeds.description: TypeScript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps. Contribute to o1-labs/o1js development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: Actions are not reduced in a particular order (or not stored either I guess). "After" was a bad terminology sorry. While you are reducing, everything you do should be commutative
What I meant was that if you provide some spesific hash of a set of actions then these actions are not reduced a second time. You can always give an empty hash and choose to reduce all of them always

well actions are a merkle list:
actionState_{n+1} = hash(action, actionState_n)
so I'd say FIFO not LIFO

the action state is what's stored on the account and you can use it as a precondition.
so as long as you prove that you can reach the _current_ action state by hashing actions starting from any earlier action state, you have _proved_ that these actions were indeed sent to the account
so you have to use the correct order, and you have to prove the hash chain up until the latest action

I recently wanted to tackle the following problem: if processing actions in your circuit takes too long, you might not be able to process them fast enough to keep up with the chain, and fall behind. Say that there are 100 pending actions and your circuit only can handle the full processing of 10

The idea is that you can do the full processing (what we call "reducing") of the first (oldest) 10 pending actions, and also create a proof that you can connect the end state with the current onchain state, via a hash chain
So for the remaining 90 actions you don't have to do your usual full processing, but ONLY the hashing
And by using a recursive proof you escape the static-size limitation
I implemented this idea here: https://github.com/mitschabaude/o1js-offchain-state/blob/main/contracts/src/action-state-prover.ts
thanks
this makes sense
@gregor Sorry to ask again, but what does an account update that only adds an action look like?
Does it set the `actions` field?

I'm guessing: you can arbitrarily set the `actions` field,
when "reducing" you set it to the remainder (always empty?),
reason I'm asking is because I want to partially go through the actions
(to avoid hitting account update limit), in a FIFO order,
so I'm imagining I can prove that after some merkle path, you have this other merkle path that ends in the `empty_hash` (defined in `mina_base/zkapp_account.ml`), such that you can
set the actions field to the merkle list it would be if only the prefix we skipped was included.
Or does o1js already support something like this?
I'd still like to know what an account update that adds an action looks like though
I see the example already does something like what I want (I think?)
Yeah as you said adding an action corresponds to populating the actions field
It sounds like it but I'm not sure I fully understood your description of what you want
But yeah the example goes partially though the actions
But it doesn't involve adding new actions
so you can't remove actions?
No it's like an append only list
makes sense
so what you put in the actions field is implicitly added to the merkle list?
hence why it's a list of lists I suppose
Yes exactly
Yeah it's a list of lists so that one action can be multiple field elements
what happens if you set the actions field to something else?
will it still work?
e.g. just Field(0)
You mean a field element instead of a list of lists. You'd get a type error 😁
Yeah but what if I ignore the TS error?
Then multiple parts of the code will throw an error
And in the end, the graphql intf won't accept the tx
hmm
thanks
@gregor one more question, sorry: How come actions aren't processed using recursion?
You mean why doesn't the builtin o1js reducer logic use recursion?
yes

Good question! I guess I just tried to find one possible way of doing it. It has a max static size limitation which could be conquered with recursion. But recursion adds more overhead. So there's trade-offs. I definitely don't want the builtin o1js circuits to be viewed as the only way to do things -- see them as a userland pattern that you could modify to your needs
thanks
This makes me think, if actions are added fast enough, you can effectively DoS a contract.
I think it's probable that you can always keep up with a powerful machine, but I think the opposite is also probable.
Imagine 300 actions per block
By the time you submit your proof, your precondition fails (and wastes fees, since https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/discussions/12000#discussioncomment-6729948 hasn't been addressed)

embeds.title: Updated Transaction Snark Statement · MinaProtocol mina · Discussio...
embeds.description: As part of making the network secure against transaction pool DDoS attacks once zkApps are introduced to the network, we are splitting up transaction application within a block into 2 distinct phas...

messages.content: You need to redo the work now, for another 300 actions, and so on...
I think it's necessary that Mina keep track of what the action state was for the previous 2 blocks or so
But even then, if you fall behind, eventually this won't be enough
Maybe there's no way to work around this except for increasing the prover speed.
If it's possible to prove 10^10 actions per average block time, then it won't be a feasible attack.

> I think it's necessary that Mina keep track of what the action state was for the previous 2 blocks or so
We actually already do this, since Matthew foresaw your scenario. We keep track of the state for the last 5 blocks 🙌
How do I put that in the precondition?
and nice
matthew being mrmr1993 or something?
yes that's him. it works so that the value in your precondition only has to match one of the 5 (you can't explicitly say which one)
wtf
well it makes sense
very nice
there is so much documentations missing
https://github.com/MinaProtocol/MIPs/issues/13

embeds.title: Clarify zkApp MIP · Issue #13 · MinaProtocol/MIPs
embeds.description: It is vague on details and misleading at certain points, e.g. phrasing such as "Account A has granted a smart contract access to drain his funds" which isn't how it really works under...

messages.content: made an issue about it
